profileText: A Delegate from New Jersey; born in Gortlea, County Donegal, Ireland, in 1729; immigrated to the United States in 1750; engaged in agricultural pursuits; was commissioned lieutenant colonel of militia in Hunterdon County, N.J., April 10, 1771; commissioned colonel of a battalion of Minutemen on February 15, 1776; appointed commissary general of issues by the Continental Congress on June 18, 1777; Member of the Continental Congress in 1784 and 1785; died in Flemington, N.J., on June 24, 1800; interment in Old Stone Church, Bethlehem Township, Hunterdon County, N.J.

researchRecord.description: The papers of Charles Stewart contain correspondence, official accounts, reports, and legal papers, chiefly from Charles Stewart's tenure as Commissary General of Issues during the American Revolution. These materials document the acquisition and distribution of food and clothing supplies for the Continental Army troops. Charles Stewart's correspondents include George Washington, Nathanael Greene, Benedict Arnold, Alexander Hamilton, and John Hancock. Transcripts of letters, 1778-1780, from Charles Stewart to Moore Furman (from originals in New Jersey State Archives), drafts and copies of other letters written by Charles Stewart, and some family documents are included. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.
